bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, July 7, 1949

div1.p: Hench is sorry to hear of Emilie Lawrence Reed's worsening health. He assures Blossom Reed that the Reed Memorial Association payments made to her mother will continue to be paid to her.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, July 7, 1949
div1.opener:
Y F
July 7, 1949
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summitt
Pennsylvania
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
It was so nice of you to write me expressing interest in our
recent work. It is really going along very well and it has already been
confirmed from several sources but we have much work ahead and the extreme
rarity of the material is a great handicap which will be corrected as the
months pass by.

I am so sorry to hear of the progressive illness of your mother.
I hardly know whether or not to say that I wish for release of her spirit
so that she may have a fuller life elsewhere, but I am greatly impressed
by the devoted care which you have given her for so long.

As for the personal part of your letter, let me tell you the
following: Somewhere I have a memorandum on the policy of the Walter
Reed Memorial Association but at the moment I cannot lay my hands on it.
I am sure, however, that it is the purpose of the Association to continue
to do for your family what Walter Reed would want done and I am sure that
after your mother's death your father would naturally want you and your
brother to receive whatever help was necessary from the fund. That is
certainly much more important than the erection of some small memorial
which could not in any way compare to the monuments to your father now
in existence. Rest assure that as long as I am a member of the board and
so far as I am able to do so, the interests of his children will be the
prime concern of the board.

I shall look up this point in the minutes of the previous meetings
as soon as I can and let you know further.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
